AUSTRALIA

Qantas (QAN AT) - Analysts see the Co. as unlikely to return to profit before FY22, while traffic and capacity will return to FY19 levels by FY23. (Newswires)

Other News - China Global Times said China has the power to hurt the Australian economy but won't fire the first shot, while it hopes Australia can release more goodwill and take more measures to repair its relationship with its largest trading partner China. (Twitter)

 

JAPAN

SOUTH KOREA

Other News - South Korea Finance Minister Hong said they will step up efforts for an economic recovery after the coronavirus pandemic, as the nation returns to normal activities. (Yonhap)

subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC

FOMC Minutes stated that all members agreed the Fed remained committed to using full range of tools to support the economy and that the coronavirus pandemic would weigh significantly on the economy, employment and inflation for the near term, as well as poses considerable downside risks to the outlook in the medium term. Minutes noted that System Open Market Account manager suggested that repo operation be made a backstop by raising the min-rate as conditions have improved in the funding markets and FOMC saw no risk that the EFFR would move below the target range when an IOER hike was raised. A few participants suggested the balance sheet could be used to reinforce forward guidance regarding the path of the federal funds rate through purchases of Treasury securities on a scale necessary to keep yields at short- to medium-term maturities capped at specified levels for a period of time.

FOMC Minutes stated that some commented the Committee could make its forward guidance for the path for the federal funds rate more explicit. For example, the Committee could adopt outcome-based forward guidance that would specify macroeconomic outcomes—such as a certain level of the unemployment rate or of the inflation rate—that must be achieved before it would consider raising the target rate. Furthermore, respondents to Desk surveys attached almost no probability to the FOMC implementing negative policy rates.

Several also said the FOMC may need to provide further clarity regarding its intentions for asset purchases as uncertainty about the evolution of the purchases could increase over time. A number of participants emphasized that regulators should encourage banks to prepare for possible downside scenarios by further limiting payouts to shareholders, thereby preserving loss-absorbing capital. (Newswires)

 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US VP Pence said the White House is mulling additional COVID-19 travel restrictions and notes it is watching Latin American countries, such as Brazil, very closely. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi expects there to be movement on coronavirus bill next week. (Newswires)

US COVID-19 cases rose 1.6% to 1,528,235 and the death toll rose 1.5% to 91,664 (Prev. +1.0%). (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 35,704 (Prev. 35,341) which is an increase of 363 vs. Prev. 545. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

US President Trump tweeted harsh rhetoric against China in which he stated it was the incompetence of China and nothing else that did this mass worldwide killing. (Twitter)

US Senate passes Bill aimed at increasing oversight of Chinese companies which could require Chinese firms listed in the US to de-list from US exchanges, and requires companies to certify no government control. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry said China will take necessary countermeasures on US' wrong behaviours (regarding Taiwan), while it added the US must bear the consequences. (Newswires)

China urged US to cut official ties with Taiwan and to stop upgrading substantive relations, interfering in China's internal affairs and to stop undermining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, as well as US/China relations. (Global Times)

China Global Times said China has the power to hurt the Australian economy but won't fire the first shot, while it hopes Australia can release more goodwill and take more measures to repair its relationship with its largest trading partner China. (Twitter)

Japan on Thursday is to lift the state of emergency in Osaka, Kyoto and Hyogo, but will keep it in Tokyo area and Northern Hokkaido. (NHK)

 

UK/EU

BoE Governor Bailey does not rule out negative rates on principle and the BoE is keen to observe how the economy has responded to recent cuts, while he added they will review purchase of risky assets and that having tools to act rapidly is important. Governor Bailey also said the challenge for us at the moment is getting inflation to return to target and acknowledged he has changed his position on negative rates a bit, while he added that there are good reasons to think pass through would be different which might be weaker and that there are mixed reviews on negative rates. (Newswires)

EU's Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier said he remains convinced with mutual respect and constructive engagement by the UK, we can move forward in the limited available time. (Newswires)

  • UK CPI (Apr) Y/Y 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 1.5%). (Newswires)
  • EU HICP (Apr F) Y/Y 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -4.983M vs. Exp. 1.151M (Prev. -0.745M). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump and French President Macron discussed concerns about the deterioration of foreign interference in Libya and have agreed on an urgent need for de-escalation. (Newswires)

US President Trump's administration is reportedly considering further sanctions/legal steps to block Iranian oil exports to Venezuela, according to reports citing US officials. (WSJ)

US issued fresh Iranian sanctions and has sanctioned the Iranian Interior Minister according to the US Treasury website. In related news, US Secretary of State Pompeo said they have warned that doing business with Iranian-linked vessels risk "severe consequences". (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Kaplan (voter) said cannot legislate or stimulate consumer activity and we need to invest in testing so consumers feel safe, while he thinks the Fed and fiscal authorities will need to do more. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Stocks traded higher on Wednesday, underpinned by hopes of an economic recovery as every US state has now at least partially reopened; energy and communications led gains, and all eleven sectors were green; small caps had a solid day, and dividend baskets also had a good session, while value actually outperformed growth baskets (the latter is now positive ytd). The USD printed its third day of losses amid the constructive risk tone, though its moves are also influenced by the EUR’s recent rally, as the bloc gets its act together with regards to virus relief. Oil was higher, supported by bullish inventory data. Yields were lower across the Treasury curve, and the supply of new 20-year bonds was decent. The Fed’s meeting minutes added little new information to the narrative, although the Fed impresses it still has scope to tweak programmes and tighten forward guidance; there was also the now customary call on fiscal authorities to help out with the heavy lifting. Lowe’s (LOW) saw a solid beat on EPS and revenue while SSS smashed analyst expectations, rising 12.3% (exp. +3.44%). LOW also noted that its strong sales are continuing into May. Target (TGT) also saw top and bottom-line beats with firmer comp sales than expected (+10.8%, exp. +7.5%) driven by a 141% rise in e-commerce; OM’s beat, GM’s missed. Analog Devices (ADI) beat on EPS while revenue was in line, while its guidance was firmer than expected; OM’s beat, GM’s missed. Royal Caribbean (RCL) missed on EPS, and saw a slight revenue beat. Initial reports suggested Disney (DIS) were to release its reopening plans for its Florida parks tomorrow, however, the story was later rebuffed by CNBC citing DIS officials. AT&T (T) will reportedly be more open to a sale of its money-losing DirecTV unit, according to FBN. Apple (AAPL) has reportedly accelerated its plan to move iPhone production to India and Vietnam as it looks to diversify manufacturing risks away from China amid souring US/China relations, according to DigiTimes citing supply chain sources. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) announced it will stop selling its talcum powder in the US and Canada, but it will continue to sell the product outside of North America. Casinos (BYD, PENN, LVS, WYNN, MGM, CZR) in Louisiana and Mississippi are set to reopen this weekend, while Las Vegas looks set to reopen in June. SPX +1.7% at 2972, NDX +2% at 9485, DJIA +1.5% at 24,576.

Treasury yields fell across the curve by between 1-3bps and major curve spreads are mixed at settlement. As US players arrived, the curve was bear-steepening moderately, perhaps due to corporate supply and pre-20-year auction hedging, with the complex content to look through moves in equity markets. However, buying action was seen in wake of reports that the Senate had passed a bill that aimed at increasing oversight of Chinese companies, which could require Chinese firms listed in the US to de-list from US exchanges, and required companies to certify no government control. The story, while not a law yet, reinforces the tensions between US/China. The new 20-year auction was decent, although tailed 0.7bps, though there is no recent auction history to compare the metrics. Last week, analysts had modelled a high yield of 1.26bps, and the stop-out level was 4bps richer than that. Cover was decent at 2.53x when compared to similar auctions, while indirect participation was also encouraging (as seen in the recent 10s and 30s auction), suggesting that there is still foreign demand for USTs even at these low yields. T-note (M0) futures settled 7 ticks higher at 139-02+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - May 20th: Stocks bounce back despite vaccine concerns
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: Senate pass bill aimed at Chinese Co’s, China urge US to cut Taiwan ties; Fed minutes as expected, Successful 20-year auction
  • COMING UP: Data: Japanese Trade Balance, EZ, UK & US PMIs (Flash), US Initial Jobless Claims & Existing Home Sales Events: CBRT & SARB Rate Decisions Speakers: Fed’s Powell, Clarida & Williams, ECB’s Panetta Supply: Spain, UK & US Earnings: NVIDIA & Generali

MARKET WRAP

Stocks traded higher on Wednesday, underpinned by hopes of an economic recovery as every US state has now at least partially reopened; energy and communications led gains, and all eleven sectors were green; small caps had a solid day, and dividend baskets also had a good session, while value actually outperformed growth baskets (the latter is now positive ytd). The USD printed its third day of losses amid the constructive risk tone, though its moves are also influenced by the EUR’s recent rally, as the bloc gets its act together with regards to virus relief. Oil was higher, supported by bullish inventory data. Yields were lower across the Treasury curve, and the supply of new 20-year bonds was decent. The Fed’s meeting minutes added little new information to the narrative, although the Fed impresses it still has scope to tweak programmes and tighten forward guidance; there was also the now customary call on fiscal authorities to help out with the heavy lifting.

VACCINE

MODERNA: An interesting observation was made by Bloomberg’s market commentator John Authers; recapping this week’s price action, he observes that on Monday Moderna (MRNA) gave an upbeat assessment on the performance of its COVID drug, it then sold shares on Tuesday, and then late on Tuesday, a medical journal said Moderna did not produce data critical to assessing vaccine. The Monday story gave hopes that a second wave can be avoided, and stocks rallied; but Tuesday’s update dragged stocks lower. Authers says “the episode tells us there is more room for the market to rise, if people can be given an excuse,” and “it also shows the depth of desire for someone to come up with a vaccine that can short-circuit what looks like being at least another 12-months of nervousness, fear, ever more fractious politics, and a sluggish economy — and that the current price is based on some bearish assumptions.” Crucially, he argues that the episode demonstrates that, given so few precedents to guide traders, and given the trading community are not scientific experts, it is ‘rival narratives’ which is driving stock price action. The piece is definitely worth a read, and highlights three/four narratives which have been ‘abused’ by markets: “It’s Just A Flu” (used as a justification for minimizing the entire pandemic); “Herd Immunity” (to justify carrying on with economic activity as usual, and risking lives); “Flatten the Curve” (to justify continuing with tight lockdown measures even when they have served their purpose); and possibly “A Vaccine Will Cure Everything.”

NORTH AMERICA

CHINESE STOCK LISTINGS: The US Senate passed a bill aimed at increasing oversight of Chinese companies; could require Chinese firms listed in the US to de-list from US exchanges and requires companies to certify no government control. Note that the bill will now go to the House for a vote. Analysts have been closely watching US/China headlines for signs that harsh rhetoric is backed with legislative actions; any laws that underpin a restricting of portfolio flows is being seen as quite a negative. The passing of this bill suggests that some of the heated rhetoric is being backed up by action, and the desk is watching for further developments and details. The announcement saw downside in NQ June ’20 futures, and more acute losses in Chinese ADRs such as BIDU, JD, BABA, TME, NTES, TCOM.

TAIWAN: China has urged US to cut official ties with Taiwan and to stop upgrading substantive relations, interfering in China's internal affairs and to stop undermining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, as well as US/China relations. This comes as US' relationship with Taiwan is seen as a threat to China; reports noted that US is attempting to squeeze Huawei via Taiwan's TSMC, which was seen as a restriction to China's influence over Taiwan.  Meanwhile, at her inauguration speech, "anti-China" President Tsai said China would never leave any room for “Taiwan independence”. China's Foreign Ministry later stated China will take necessary countermeasures on US' wrong behaviours (regarding Taiwan), adding the US must bear the consequences. China added US actions on Taiwan violates the promise it made and sent the wrong signal to the Taiwan independence forces.

ASIA-PAC

STIMULUS WATCH: Ahead of the NPC this week (our full preview of the NPC event can be found here), analyst expectations for more stimulus from the Chinese government are building, the FT reports. One analyst said “the NPC will send a clear signal on the level of economic stimulus in the coming months,” and the stimulus “is going to be a strong one, but a runaway building boom is unlikely to happen given the long-term damage it does to the economy.” Meanwhile, there is focus on remarks from JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, which have suggested that central banks will need to ramp-up QE to prevent a sharp rise in bond yields, Bloomberg reported, stating that the level of expected increase in supply this year (around USD 2.1trln) is offsetting the USD 1.9trln demand for bonds by USD 200bln, implying upward pressure on yields and that more issuance adds to the case for higher rates and steeper curves.

AUSTRALIA/CHINA: With tensions rising between the two nations after Australia’s push to examine whether the coronavirus came from China, it has seen a deterioration in relations between the two which saw China put tariffs on Australian barley. China Global Times wrote today that China has the power to hurt the Australian economy, but it will not fire the first shot. China hopes Australia can release more goodwill and take more measures to repair its relationship with its largest trading partner.

CENTRAL BANKS

BOE: Governor Bailey once again noted how the bank does not rule out negative rates on principle. The Governor added the BoE is keen to observe how the economy has responded to recent cuts, adding we will review the purchase of risky assets, noting having tools to act rapidly is important. Further on NIRP, he noted the financial system structure of other countries with negative rates is important (note, Tenreyo recently noted how she believes they are positive in Europe). Bailey later added there are mixed reviews on NIRP, says there are good reasons to think pass through would be different. Bailey also noted that the challenge currently is getting inflation to return to target.

FED MINUTES: The Fed’s meeting minutes from the April confab came in largely as expected, with policymakers pledging to act as appropriate to support the recovery, and rates will be left at low levels until participants are convinced that the recovery is on track. The FOMC also noted actions taken by the Fed has helped improve market functioning. There was no explicit mention of negative rates, although a Desk Survey was cited that suggested respondents saw no probability of NIRP. Yield curve control was alluded to, with a few participants noted that yield curve control could be used to reinforce forward guidance via capping short- to medium-term yields at specified levels. On fiscal stimulus, it repeated that greater fiscal support may be necessary if the downturn persists. There was also a nudge at banks, with a number of participants emphasising that regulators should encourage banks to prepare for possible downside scenarios by further limiting payouts to shareholders. The Committee could make forward guidance more explicit, the minutes suggested, by perhaps adopting out-come based guidance or calendar-based guidance, which could specify certain unemployment rate of inflation targets. These minutes were always expected to be a bit of a stale, non-event, and the market reaction has generally confirmed that hypothesis. Accordingly, it is safe to assume that the minutes and recent commentary suggests that the Fed is leaving policy where it is until it sees the recovery emerging, and still has tools to both add/tweak. In future communications, it is also worth keeping an eye on the tone of the FOMC participants' view on formalising its current QE programme, some analysts said.

FED SPEAK: Fed's Kaplan (voter) mentioned how consumer activity cannot be legislated nor stimulated, stating we need to invest in testing, so consumers feel safe. Kaplan thinks the Fed and fiscal authorities will need to do more. His comments on fiscal action and more monetary action are in line with other Fed officials, notably Powell. Powell has previously said the Fed could further help companies with liquidity issues for a while, but over time, more fiscal help will be needed – a strong hint to fiscal policymakers as they debate the next tranche of stimulus. Powell on the weekend said at least three-to-six more months of government support would be required. Bullard (non-voter, dove) also spoke very much reiterating previous comments but added that a virus resurgence is unlikely to derail recovery efforts.

SARB: The SARB is expected to cut rates by 50bps to 50-year low 3.75%, though there is a risk it will cut by a larger magnitude. There have been calls for the SARB to buy government bonds in primary markets, though it is expected to lean against this political pressure for now. Click here for full preview.

CBRT: All 15 analysts polled by Reuters expect the Central Bank to implement another cut to the Weekly Repo Rate, currently at 8.75%. However, as is usually the case, economists are split over the magnitude of the reduction – with the range varying between 100-50bps and the median pointing to the lower end. Click here for full preview.

FIXED INCOME

T-NOTE (M0) FUTURES SETTLED 7 TICKS HIGHER AT 139-02+

Treasury yields fell across the curve by between 1-3bps and major curve spreads are mixed at settlement. As US players arrived, the curve was bear-steepening moderately, perhaps due to corporate supply and pre-20-year auction hedging, with the complex content to look through moves in equity markets. However, buying action was seen in wake of reports that the Senate had passed a bill that aimed at increasing oversight of Chinese companies, which could require Chinese firms listed in the US to de-list from US exchanges, and required companies to certify no government control. The story, while not a law yet, reinforces the tensions between US/China. The new 20-year auction was decent, although tailed 0.7bps, though there is no recent auction history to compare the metrics. Last week, analysts had modelled a high yield of 1.26bps, and the stop-out level was 4bps richer than that. Cover was decent at 2.53x when compared to similar auctions, while indirect participation was also encouraging (as seen in the recent 10s and 30s auction), suggesting that there is still foreign demand for USTs even at these low yields.

CRUDE

WTI (N0) SETTLED USD 1.53 HIGHER AT USD 33.49; BRENT (N0) SETTLED USD 1.10 HIGHER AT USD 35.75

Crude prices continue to find their footing as front-month futures unwind extreme pessimism on bullish inventory data, although futures pared somewhat in later trade. Following the WTI June contract expiry, which saw the front-month spread move into backwardation and went by relatively smoothly when compared to the May contract’s historic final few trading sessions, the front-month spread has returned into contango, albeit considerably less steep than the “super contango” seen before, supporting the thesis of a tightening physical market. That notion rings true post this week’s US inventory data, which saw a draw in the private release on Tuesday, supported the energy complex overnight, and was confirmed by the EIA data today. Crude stocks fell by 5mln bbls, marking the second consecutive draw, while the key Cushing hub saw its stocks draw by 5.6mln bbls, a trend which is critical for allowing nearby WTI holders to avoid another break down of the futures market amid storage capacity concerns. The EIA also reported distillates and gasoline both built by 3.8mln and 2.8mln each respectively, while refinery utilisation rose by 1.5%; crude production fell by 100k BPD to 11.5mln BPD. Elsewhere, OPEC Secretary-General Barkindo spoke today saying that oil supply and demand fundamentals are gradually converging. Dallas Fed’s Kaplan said he thinks oil well shut-ins are at their peak and said that a lot would come back by the year-end.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +1.7% at 2972, NDX +2% at 9485, DJIA +1.5% at 24,576

SECTORS: Energy +3.8%, Financials +2.2%, Technology +2.1%, Industrials +1.8%, Communications +1.8%, Materials +1.6%, Discretionary +1.4%, Staples +1.1%, Real Estate +0.9%, Utilities +0.5%, Health Care +0.1%.

EARNINGS: Lowe’s (LOW) saw a solid beat on EPS and revenue while SSS smashed analyst expectations, rising 12.3% (exp. +3.44%). LOW also noted that its strong sales are continuing into May. Target (TGT) also saw top and bottom-line beats with firmer comp sales than expected (+10.8%, exp. +7.5%) driven by a 141% rise in e-commerce; OM’s beat, GM’s missed. Analog Devices (ADI) beat on EPS while revenue was in line, while its guidance was firmer than expected; OM’s beat, GM’s missed. Royal Caribbean (RCL) missed on EPS, and saw a slight revenue beat.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Initial reports suggested Disney (DIS) were to release its reopening plans for its Florida parks tomorrow, however, the story was later rebuffed by CNBC citing DIS officials. AT&T (T) will reportedly be more open to a sale of its money-losing DirecTV unit, according to FBN. Apple (AAPL) has reportedly accelerated its plan to move iPhone production to India and Vietnam as it looks to diversify manufacturing risks away from China amid souring US/China relations, according to DigiTimes citing supply chain sources. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) announced it will stop selling its talcum powder in the US and Canada, but it will continue to sell the product outside of North America. Casinos (BYD, PENN, LVS, WYNN, MGM, CZR) in Louisiana and Mississippi are set to reopen this weekend, while Las Vegas looks set to reopen in June. Google (GOOG) and Dell (DELL) launched a hybrid storage solution to offer simplified management of private and public cloud storage. Roku (ROKU) and AT&T’s (T) WarnerMedia are reportedly aiming for a deal to get HBO Max streaming service on Roku’s platform, but it will not appear on Amazon’s (AMZN) firestick until May 27th, according to Variety. Haliburton (HAL) cut its dividend, Northrop Grumman (NOC) raised its dividend

EUROPE CLOSES: EURO STOXX 50 +1.35% at 2942, FTSE 100 +1.13% at 6070, DAX +1.40% at 11230, CAC 40 +0.87% at 4497, IBEX 35 +1.10% at 6682, FTSE MIB +1.04% at 17213, SMI +0.32% at 9796.

DATA

EZ CONSUMER CONFIDENCE: The data ticked up to -18.8 from a previous revised -22, which beat expectations of a fall to -23.8, the first sign in data of a rebound in the EZ economy, Pantheon said, although the increase was only slight. The consultancy believes this increase makes sense as lockdown measures start to ease and given the prior months report was surveyed in the middle of lockdown. “The headline index continues to signal severe weakness in retail sales, which is exactly the right message for Q2 as a whole” which points to a slow process of lifting lockdowns and a small recovery in retail sales growth by the middle of Q2. Pantheon also highlights that the data is particularly sensitive to turning points in changes in activity which will likely be seen in tomorrow’s PMI, “headlines will look great, but that doesn’t mean activity has returned to normal” the consultancy concludes.

CANADA CPI (APR.): Canadian consumer prices declined 0.7% M/M in April, a little deeper than the expected decline of 0.6%; the Y/Y measure printed -0.2% against an expected -0.1%; the three core BOC measures declined by 3bps to 1.8%. Capital Economics argues that with energy prices enjoying a rebound, headline inflation is unlikely to fall much further below these levels, and explains that core inflation was little changed in the months due to items like clothing and electricity; "these were discarded as outliers in the three core measures, while StatsCan was unable to calculate prices for some other heavily-affected components like airfares and travel tours and so simply imputed that, despite the complete collapse in demand for those services, prices moved in line with the overall CPI index," CapEco says. Quirks have meant that only one of the three core measures declined (common measure fell to 1.6% from 1.7%, the trimmed and median were unchanged at 2.0% and 1.8% respectively). "We had assumed that inflation for many goods and services would plummet amid essentially zero demand, but StatsCan’s method for imputing these prices means we may have to revisit our core inflation forecasts," CapEco says, "Nevertheless, we doubt an average of the three measures will be returning to over 2% again any time soon."

FX WRAP

USD, EUR: The dollar saw a third consecutive day of declines, with DXY finding support around the 99-figure. After 99.00 was hit the USD bounced back from the lows some reprieve was seen although the buck remained lower on the day given the overall positive risk sentiment as economies continue to reopen. There was nothing to concern USD traders within the FOMC meeting minutes, which largely reiterates the Fed’s stance, and hints at YCC/more explicit guidance ahead. The EUR has continued to rise since the Franco-German EU recovery fund proposal, and also supported by firmer risk sentiment detracting the Buck’s appeal. EURUSD extended on gains, finding resistance at 1.10 from the 1.08 low at the beginning of the week. JPMorgan notes this sort of price action has been typical and remains biased towards a short USD stance, at least for now. The desk suggests 1.1000/20 is key, and a break above it would put more pressure on shorts. JPM also notes asset managers were buyers of EUR yesterday and, if this persists against a backdrop of still ample spec shorts, it would consider revisiting a tactical long position.

GBP: Despite a falling dollar and positive risk sentiment, GBP saw downside amid continued rhetoric from the MPC that negative rates are in the toolkit, even though they might not be seen in the immediate term. Meanwhile, CPI data was softer than expected in April, slowing to 0.8% Y/Y (exp. 0.9%, prev. 1.5% Y/Y), while the M/M print declined by 0.2%, slightly deeper than the expected -0.1% print. BOE Governor Bailey noted the current challenge is getting inflation to return to the bank’s target. ING writes that the risk of no extension to the transition period appears a quite strong bearish argument and the desk expects GBP to re-enter a depreciation trend soon.

AUD, NZD: Antipodeans traded firmer, although AUD lagged NZD amid the deterioration of the relationship with China; a Global Times piece suggested that China has the power to “hurt” the Australian economy but it will not fire the first shot,  hoping Australia can release more goodwill and take more measures to repair its relationship with its largest trading partner. TD Securities said the AUD looks like it is closest to either a potential breakout or backslide, and the desk eyes the end-April high of 0.6570, a level which broke today, suggesting a sustained move beyond this level would make the argument that we are to head lower soon rather difficult. TD says “at 3.4 standard deviations above our high frequency fair value estimate of 0.6300, the AUD looks very stretched at these levels. Even on a good day, that would leave us reluctant to embrace a rally from here.”

CAD: The Loonie rose today in line with risk sentiment, rising crude prices, and a falling USD. CPI was the focus, although there was little price action in the aftermath; the BOC’s core metrics only ticked down modestly. USDCAD has stuck around 1.39 for the majority of the session; Scotiabank “look for choppy range trading to extend and, as such, feel that scope for additional CAD gains beyond the 1.3850/1.39 zone is limited for now.”

JPY: The Yen firmed against a falling dollar despite a decent approach to risk elsewhere, although moves were thin trading within the 107.34-107.98 parameters. Technicians at Citi see a potential of USDJPY in danger of breaking higher, suggesting “the pattern now looks like an inverted head and shoulders with a neckline at 107.63 – we could see a move to 109.40.”

EMFX: Emerging Market FX was generally firmer against the dollar today, apart from TRY heading into tomorrow’s CBRT decision. MXN, RUB & ZAR (SARB tomorrow too) saw solid gains with the former two benefitting from the continued inventory draws being seen in the US driving oil higher, suggesting supply woes are starting to abate. Meanwhile, the ZAR cleared 18.00 to the downside against the buck and continues to extend beyond the figure at pixel time amid firmer than expected (and the prior) retail sales. MUFG highlights that EMFX countries are struggling to contain the coronavirus as well as DM economies. Meanwhile, MUFG sees a risk of a second wave greater in the US than Europe given Trump’s optimism to reopen the economy quickly, and if that were to happen will see a less likely chance of travel restrictions being eased to the South America countries

subject: US COVID-19 cases at 1.6% at 1,528,235 (prev. +1,504,830); death toll +1.5% at 91,664 (prev. +1% at 90,340)
TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-Note (M0) futures settled 7 ticks higher at 139-02+
analysis_details: • Treasury yields fell across the curve by between 1-3bps and major curve spreads are mixed at settlement. As US players arrived, the curve was bear-steepening moderately, perhaps due to corporate supply and pre-20-year auction hedging, with the complex content to look through moves in equity markets. However, buying action was seen in wake of reports that the Senate had passed a bill that aimed at increasing oversight of Chinese companies, which could require Chinese firms listed in the US to de-list from US exchanges, and required companies to certify no government control. The story, while not a law yet, reinforces the tensions between US/China. The new 20-year auction was decent, although tailed 0.7bps, though there is no recent auction history to compare the metrics. Last week, analysts had modelled a high yield of 1.26bps, and the stop-out level was 4bps richer than that. Cover was decent at 2.53x when compared to similar auctions, while indirect participation was also encouraging (as seen in the recent 10s and 30s auction), suggesting that there is still foreign demand for USTs even at these low yields.

subject: BOC's Lane reiterates the bank does not think a further rate cut would be advisable and says "while we never say never", the banks decision is not to cut rates again
WTI (N0) settled USD 1.53 higher at USD 33.49; Brent (N0) settled USD 1.10 higher at USD 35.75
analysis_details: Crude prices continue to find their footing as front-month futures unwind extreme pessimism on bullish inventory data, although futures pared somewhat in later trade. Following the WTI June contract expiry, which saw the front-month spread move into backwardation and went by relatively smoothly when compared to the May contract’s historic final few trading sessions, the front-month spread has returned into contango, albeit considerably less steep than the “super contango” seen before, supporting the thesis of a tightening physical market. That notion rings true post this week’s US inventory data, which saw a draw in the private release on Tuesday, supported the energy complex overnight, and was confirmed by the EIA data today. Crude stocks fell by 5mln bbls, marking the second consecutive draw, while the key Cushing hub saw its stocks draw by 5.6mln bbls, a trend which is critical for allowing nearby WTI holders to avoid another break down of the futures market amid storage capacity concerns. The EIA also reported distillates and gasoline both built by 3.8mln and 2.8mln each respectively, while refinery utilisation rose by 1.5%; crude production fell by 100k BPD to 11.5mln BPD. Elsewhere, OPEC Secretary General Barkindo spoke today saying that oil supply and demand fundamentals are gradually converging. Dallas Fed’s Kaplan said he thinks oil well shut-ins are at their peak and said that a lot would come back by the year-end.

subject: SNAP ANALYSIS: Fed minutes as expected; Committee alludes to YCC, and tweaks to forward guidance ahead
analysis_details:
The Fed’s meeting minutes from the April confab came in largely as expected, with policymakers pledging to act as appropriate to support the recovery, and rates will be left at low levels until participants are convinced that the recovery is on track. The FOMC also noted actions taken by the Fed has helped improve market functioning. There was no explicit mention of negative rates, although a Desk Survey was cited that suggested respondents saw no probability of NIRP. Yield curve control was alluded to, with a few participants noted that yield curve control could be used to reinforce forward guidance via capping short- to medium-term yields at specified levels. On fiscal stimulus, it repeated that greater fiscal support may be necessary if the downturn persists. There was also a nudge at banks, with a number of participants emphasising that regulators should encourage banks to prepare for possible downside scenarios by further limiting payouts to shareholders. The Committee could make forward guidance more explicit, the minutes suggested, by perhaps adopting out-come based guidance or calendar-based guidance, which could specify certain unemployment rate of inflation targets. 

ANALYSIS: These minutes were always expected to be a bit of a stale, non-event, and the market reaction has generally confirmed that hypothesis. Accordingly, it is safe to assume that the minutes and recent commentary suggest that the Fed is leaving policy where it is until it sees the recovery emerging, and still has tools to both add/tweak. In future communications, it is also worth keeping an eye on the tone of the FOMC participants view on formalising its current QE programme, some analysts said.

subject: US Quinnipiac national poll: Biden leads Trump at 50% to 39%

BOC's Lane says  we are likely to emerge with demand and supply weaker than before, scarring associated with shutdown could lower productivity, which tends to result in higher inflation
content:
• Post crisis sectoral adjustments are likely to cause damage to Canadian productive capacity that may be profound and long lasting
  • A new challenge it is facing is a sizeable increase in financing needs by federal and provincial governments coinciding with heightened credit needs of the private sector
  • Bank analysis suggest decline in demand stemming in part from weaker business and consumer confidence is likely to have a larger effect
  • Monetary policy will continue to manage the risk that inflation could deviate persistently from its target in either direction
  • Reiterates expectation that Q2 GDP to fall between 15 and 30% from late 2019
  • Sees some reasons for optimism; layoffs are concentrated in the service sector, where during normal times labour mobility is high
  • The sharp decline in inflation is due less to overall economic slack than to some specific factors—especially the drop in prices of gasoline and travel services, as well as shifts in spending. These shifts mean that the standard consumer price index (CPI), based on the cost of a fixed basket of goods, is less meaningful.
  • Click here for full speech

subject: FOMC Minutes: SOMA manager suggested that repo operation be made a backstop by raising the min-rate as conditions have improved in the funding markets; FOMC saw no risk that the EFFR would move below the target range, when an IOER hike was raised
content:
• YCC: a few participants noted that the balance sheet could be used to reinforce forward guidance regarding the path of the federal funds rate through purchases of Treasury securities on a scale necessary to keep yields at short- to medium-term maturities capped at specified levels for a period of time
  • Some commented that the Committee could make its forward guidance for the path for the federal funds rate more explicit. For example, the Committee could adopt outcome-based forward guidance that would specify macroeconomic outcomes—such as a certain level of the unemployment rate or of the inflation rate—that must be achieved before it would consider raising the target rate.
  • Respondents to Desk surveys attached almost no probability to the FOMC implementing negative policy rates. Some survey respondents indicated that they expected modifications to the Committee’s forward guidance, but not at the current meeting.
  • Several said the FOMC may need to provide further clarity regarding its intentions for asset purchases; noted that, without further communication on this matter, uncertainty about the evolution of the purchases could increase over time.
  • A number of participants emphasized that regulators should encourage banks to prepare for possible downside scenarios by further limiting payouts to shareholders, thereby preserving loss-absorbing capital

PREVIEW: FOMC April 2020 Meeting Minutes to be released at 1400 EDT/1900 BST
analysis_details:
The minutes to the Fed’s April meeting are unlikely to be a game changer, given that the confab itself was considered a ‘holding meeting’, and there have been many Fed speakers in the three weeks that have followed, making the minutes somewhat stale (not that Fed speakers have been saying much, except they will do everything within their mandate to support the economy through this unprecedented times). And that is likely to be the underlying theme of the minutes. Elsewhere, however, we will be on the lookout for commentary on negative rates – which does not carry much favour among Fed members, though is something that they are seemingly keeping in the toolbox in case it is needed in the future – as well as any commentary on yield curve control, which analysts expect the Fed to pivot to in the months ahead to bolster its pledge to keep short-term yields anchored at historic lows for the foreseeable future. Additionally, there will likely be another call on fiscal authorities to help with the heavy lifting.   

FOMC APRIL MEETING RECAP: The Fed’s 30th April rate decision was as expected; the federal funds rate target and the interest on excess reserves were left unchanged at 0.00-0.25% and 0.10% respectively. The Fed reiterated its commitment to keep rates at current low levels until the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve its inflation and labour market goals. One key omission from its statement was references to specific amounts of asset purchases (previously it indicated that it would buy “at least” USD 500bln of Treasuries and at least USD 200bln of MBS); instead, it said it would purchase in amounts needed to support smooth market functioning, which might be taken as a pledge for limitless QE until the central bank is confident that its mandates can be met – in his press conference, Chair Powell said the Fed was waiting to see how economic conditions unfold before committing. Some traders were disappointed by the lack of explicit forward guidance within the statement; Powell reiterated that rates would remain low until the economy has ‘weathered’ the COVID impact, echoing the statement. He provided what has become customary warnings about the impending collapse of economic metrics in Q2, as a result of the virus, but thinks that Q3 might see ‘substantial growth’. The Fed chair also emphasised a willingness to do more if required. And in terms of the outlook, Powell identified medium-term risks: the virus and bringing it under control; the possibility of damage to the productive capacity of the economy; the global dimension, where negative data abroad can weigh on the US; Powell believes that the Fed has the policies to address these, but not perfectly. Another key omission was clues about yield curve control; analysts believe that the Fed will need to eventually implement a Japan/Australia style yield curve control policy that keeps a lid on shorter-dated Treasury yields – this policy would be the strong arm to bolster the central bank’s guidance that rates will be kept low. This policy is expected to be hinted at in the months ahead, likely from June, as the Fed gains more clarity on how the virus will play out. Additionally, desks believe that the Fed will continue to taper its (what has been front-loaded) asset purchases (currently running at an average clip of around USD 50bln/week) to something like USD 60-80bln per month (NOTE: this publication is released before the NY Fed update on Friday afternoon, where it may again lower the pace of purchases). However, don’t expect any updates until the aforementioned clarity can be seen; for what it is worth, Powell emphasised that the Fed would not be removing the punch bowl too quickly, or any time soon. One theme that has been in vogue in recent days is negative rates, after some Federal Funds Futures contracts rose above par, signalling a non-zero probability of negative rates ahead; Powell and Co. have heavily leaned-back against this policy tool next week; analysts are of the view that the tool would only be used if the Fed had exhausted all other options.  

POWELL SENATE TESTIMONY: Fed chair Powell repeated his pledge to maintain rates at near-zero levels until the economy had weathered the crisis, and emphasise that the passage of the CARES Act was critical to the Fed’s ability to expand credit programmes to help support the economy, and as a result of these actions, market function has improved. Elsewhere, there was little of note, in terms of new developments, within Powell’s remarks; the Fed is continuing to look into ways to accommodate additional borrowers, and is particularly looking at extending borrowing to states with low populations, the Fed chair told lawmakers. He also said that he expects the central bank’s balance sheet to gradually shrink over time; what matters is the size of the balance sheet relative to the size of the US economy, and the balance sheet does not yet raise financial stability concerns; however, analysts have viewed the balance sheet debate is a debate for another post-pandemic day.  

FISCAL ACTION: Powell has previously said the Fed could further help companies with liquidity issues for a while, but over time, more fiscal help will be needed – a strong hint to fiscal policymakers as they debate the next tranche of stimulus. Powell on the weekend said at least three-to-six more months of government support would be required. The Fed chair seems to be arguing that further support is crucial to any recovery, and that if policymakers are careful about how the economy is reopened, and people take these social distancing measures forward, then the recovery can begin fairly soon, and job losses seen since mid-March may prove to be temporary; he also argued that, assuming there is no second wave of the coronavirus, the economy will begin to recover steadily through the second half of this year.  

NEGATIVE RATES: Fed chair Powell has pushed-back heavily against the idea of negative rates, citing the mixed evidence that exists on its efficacy. However, it is worth noting that a lot of Powell’s language has clearly been structured to leave the option open to the Fed in the future, and other Fed participants (like Kashkari) have also retained this optionality. Such an approach seems sensible, analysts argue; the Fed would be able to exhaust other policy options first before resorting to more aggressive policies. The message, therefore, seems to be that negative rates are not on the radar in the near-term, but the market and policymakers seem to be retaining a non-zero chance of seeing them next year.

subject: ANALYSIS: Eurozone consumer confidence better than expected in May; first sign in data of a rebound in the EZ, Pantheon said
analysis_details: The data ticked up to -18.8 from a previous revised -22, which beat expectations of a fall to -23.8, the first sign in data of a rebound in the EZ economy, Pantheon said, although the increase was only slight. The consultancy believes this increase makes sense as lockdown measures start to ease and given the prior months report was surveyed in the middle of lockdown. “The headline index continues to signal severe weakness in retail sales, which is exactly the right message for Q2 as a whole” which points to a slow process of lifting lockdowns and a small recovery in retail sales growth by the middle of Q2. Pantheon also highlights that the data is particularly sensitive to turning points in changes in activity which will likely be seen in tomorrow’s PMI, “headlines will look great, but that doesn’t mean activity has returned to normal” the consultancy concludes.

PREVIEW: US to sell USD 20bln of new 20-year bonds at 1300 EDT/1800 BST
analysis_details:
20-YEAR ANNOUNCEMENT: The 20-year supply will be the first since 1986. At its quarterly refunding announcement, the US Treasury said it would finally issue its new 20-year maturities on 20th May, for a size of USD 20bln. The size was bigger than anticipated (USD 12-14bln was touted), and with heavier supply at the long-end of the curve, combined with no announcement of a 4- or 6-year tenor, resulted in sharp curve steepening in the wake of the announcement. 

20-YEAR SECTOR: UBS estimates that the market has cheapened the 20-year sector, noting that the sector was cheap versus 10s30s curve as well, although now seems fair; hence, UBS says, it is cheap outright. “In general, we think the sector has already been cheap due to less liquidity and the fact that the Fed owns a large portion of the issues in the 20-year sector so its future purchases are limited.” UBS argues that, given where the 3.375% May 2044 bond is trading, fair value for the 20-year issue is implied at around 1.27%; If we assume 1-2bps of liquidity premia for the new issue, the issue is likely to trade at 1.26%, the bank writes, speculating that the issue should see strong demand since a lot of indexers and Asset Liability Management hedgers will need to buy it. “You can pick-up a lot of yield as the steepest part of 10s30s curve (around 70bps) where fair value is actually 10s20s curve (60bps),” UBS says, noting that the 30-year bond has a duration of 23-years, and comparatively, the 20-year will have a duration of 17.6yrs (5.4yrs shorter), and therefore, it makes more sense to extend duration with a 20-year than a 30- year. 

HOW THE AUCTION MIGHT PERFORM: Analysts at BMO note that takedown seen at the recent 10s and 30s auctions is an encouraging detail for Wednesday's 20-year sale, and points to a solid first auction for the new bond. And the sale may garner decent foreign demand, given that the return in Treasuries hedged back into yen is attractive, and recent reports have highlighted that 10s were once again popular among Japanese investors; what will be notable is whether the positive FX hedged yield Japanese investors can earn in the 10-year sector can translate to 20s, BMO says. 

AFTER THE AUCTION: Post-auction on Wednesday May 20th, into month-end, UBS recommends a 10s20s curve flatteners, arguing that we are likely to see larger than normal index extension for the end of month rebalancing due to heavy long-end issuance this month."

subject: BOE Governor Bailey acknowledges he has changed his position on negative rates a bit, says there are good reasons to think pass through would be different, might be weaker; says there are mixed reviews on negative rates
Daily FX Wrap: Fed’s Kaplan keeps Dollar capped and BoE suppresses Sterling
content:
USD

Nothing new or untoward from current FOMC voter Kaplan, but assertions along the lines of Fed chair Powell about the need for more monetary and fiscal stimulus applied a bit more pressure on the Greenback, with the DXY breaching support just ahead of 99.000 at 99.097 (May 8 low). However, the Buck’s broader and deeper retreat was largely due to dwindling safe-haven demand amidst another upturn in risk sentiment and oil’s ongoing resurgence that persisted after the June WTI contract expiry with assistance from OPEC Secretary General Barkindo claiming that supply and demand fundamentals are gradually rebalancing.

GBP 

Having brushed off weaker than forecast UK CPI and other price data, the Pound was not quite as dismissive of BoE testimony given further references to NIRP not being ruled out among various options and tools under consideration by the MPC that may have to respond swiftly to provide additional economic support. Indeed, Sterling failed to take full advantage of the floundering Dollar as Cable stalled ahead of 1.2300 and Eur/Gbp rebounded from the low 0.8900 zone to circa 0.8970.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi has extended post-RBNZ Governor Orr gains to 0.6150+ and 1.0715 vs its US and Aussie counterparts respectively, even though the latter has managed to scale 0.6570 and peer over 0.6600. To recap, the Nzd drew extra momentum from Orr wading in to the negative rate debate and remarking that it is not likely at the current juncture, but could be in contention ‘a lot later’, while the Aud was rocked by a record drop in retail sales and the threat of wider Chinese export tariffs ahead of May PMIs.

CHF/EUR/CAD/JPY 

All benefiting at the Greenback’s expense, with the Franc back above 0.9650, Euro within a whisker of 1.1000, Loonie consolidating around 1.3875 and Yen rebounding to 107.50+ from just under 108.00 at one stage on Tuesday. The single currency is also gleaning support from latest signs of recovery from COVID-19 on the physical and economic side, while bolstered by the prospect of Eur500 bn fiscal support assuming the rescue fund is signed off next week. Elsewhere, the Cad is only marginally weaker despite deflationary Canadian CPI and the Jpy appears to be encouraged by the fact that multiple lows held again yesterday, not to mention the 200 DMA.

SCANDI/EM

The Swedish Krona has been outperforming relative to its Scandinavian peer for the most part, but both are on course to post gains vs the Euro as they maintain upward trajectories towards 10.5000 and 11.0000 on the grounds of less dovish Riksbank and Norges Bank stances compared to the ECB. Meanwhile, more pronounced appreciation or retracement vs the Usd has been the midweek session theme for EMs, with even the Brl on the front foot irrespective of coronavirus contagion spiralling. Elsewhere, the Zar has cleared another psychological hurdle at 18.0000 in contrast to the Try that is treading more cautiously into the CBRT regardless of the fact that Turkish and SA benchmark rates are both expected to be cut by 50 bp.

PREVIEW: SARB rate decision due around 1400 BST on Thursday 21st May 2020; expected to cut 50bps, could be more; will likely lean back against direct government bond purchases
analysis_details:
The SARB is expected to cut rates by 50bps to 50-year low 3.75%, though there is a risk it will cut by a larger magnitude. There have been calls for the SARB to buy government bonds in primary markets, though it is expected to lean against this political pressure for now.

  • EXPECTATIONS: Having lowered its Prime Rate rate by 225bps already since March, South Africa’s central bank is expected to cut rates by another 50bps to a record low of 3.75% (small risks of 25bps or 75bps+ move), as the country struggles with the COVID fallout. Ahead, the expectation is that the SARB’s key rate will remain unchanged until Q3 2021. Analysts see the South African economy contracting by 6.5% in 2020, but are optimistic that growth will pick up to 2.9% in 2021.
  • POTENTIALLY BIGGER MOVE: BNP Paribas is looking for a cut of 75-100bps at the May meeting, arguing that the SARB would likely prefer to front load any reductions in anticipation of more substantial economic pressures ahead, and says that “strong deflation in fuel prices and collapsing demand are unlikely to outweigh a weaker ZAR and its limited pass-through to CPI, averaging a 17-year low of 2.8% in 2020, breaching the lower bound of the SARB’s 3- 6% target.”
  • QE: The SARB has been buying bonds in secondary markets to assist the government’s COVID Response efforts, and its holdings have now risen to ZAR 20.6bln; desks will be paying attention to any commentary hinting at more support ahead of South Africa's 24th June budget, where the government is expected to announce further support measures. Recently, there has been calls from the ruling ANC party for the SARB to enter primary markets to support the government as the deficit ticks higher -- some policy makers have argued that money printing would lead to higher inflation and weaken the currency --although analysts expect that, for now, the normally conservative central bank will lean back against these calls.

subject: PREVIEW: CBRT Rate Decision on Thursday 21st at 12:00BST; Expectations are for a 50bps cut to 8.25% (forecast range 50-100bps cut)
content:
OVERVIEW: All 15 analysts polled by Reuters expect the Central Bank to implement another cut to the Weekly Repo Rate, currently at 8.75%. However, as is usually the case, economists are split over the magnitude of the reduction – with the range varying between 100-50bps and the median pointing to the lower end.

PRIOR MEETING: The Central Bank has cut a cumulative 1525bps since July 2019. At the most recent confab, the CBRT opted to reduce its Weekly Repo Rate by 100bps, at the top of analysts’ forecast range – taking real rates deeper into negative territory. Notably, the Central Bank assessed that risks to its year-end inflation forecasts are to the downside, whilst stating that economic activity started to weaken in mid-March due to the effects of the coronavirus pandemic on external trade, tourism, and domestic demand. On the Lira, the Bank repeated the softer currency effect on inflation is offset by weaker oil prices, net-net a favourable impact. The Bank reaffirmed its “cautious monetary stance” and said it will be determined considering the indicators of the underlying inflation trend, but emphasised that any new data or information may lead the Committee to revise its stance.

RESERVES AND LIRA: Depleting reserves has been a major factor behind the Lira’s recent weakness, with USD reserves dwindling as the Central Bank attempts to defend the Try from further depreciation. These woes prompted USD/TRY to reach all-time highs at 7.2690, surpassing the 7.2350 peak set at the height of the previous Lira crisis. As such swap lines have been requested by the CBRT, with little support from the ECB, and Fed, whilst reports of lines intstigated with the BoE and BoJ were also refuted. However, it was reported that the line with Qatar has been expanded three-fold to USD 15bln. However, desks worry about the inflation outlook given the Lira’s fragility and rising oil prices.

DATA: In terms of data, Apr CPI YY dipped to 10.94% from 11.86%, while the CBRT also lowered its end-year forecast to 9.38% from 9.76% - in-fitting with efforts to get inflation back to target. Credit Suisse believes another rate cut is warranted in the near term given the current environment, and “the risk to our three-month policy rate forecast of 7.50% is firmly to the downside”, the Swiss bank says.

ANALYSIS: Canadian consumer prices fall in April; headline might not fall further from these levels, Capital Economics thinks
analysis_details: Canadian consumer prices declined 0.7% M/M in April, a little deeper than the expected decline of 0.6%; the Y/Y measure printed -0.2% against an expected -0.1%; the three core BOC measures declined by 3bps to 1.8%. Capital Economics argues that with energy prices enjoying a rebound, headline inflation is unlikely to fall much further below these levels, and explains that core inflation was little changed in the months due to items like clothing and electricity; "these were discarded as outliers in the three core measures, while StatsCan was unable to calculate prices for some other heavily-affected components like air fares and travel tours and so simply imputed that, despite the complete collapse in demand for those services, prices moved in line with the overall CPI index," CapEco says. Quirks have meant that only one of the three core measures declined (common measure fell to 1.6% from 1.7%, the trimmed and median were unchanged at 2.0% and 1.8% respectively). "We had assumed that inflation for many goods and services would plummet amid essentially zero demand, but StatsCan’s method for imputing these prices means we may have to revisit our core inflation forecasts," CapEco says, "Nevertheless, we doubt an average of the three measures will be returning to over 2% again any time soon."

subject: US EQUITY OPEN: US indices open with decent gains paring prior day losses; Energy and Industrials lead
analysis_details:
WHAT’S GOING ON: US equities have opened with decent gains, the VIX is lower, Treasury yields are flat, the dollar is down for a third day; oil trades with a positive bias after private inventory data on Tuesday showed headline crude stocks drew down and another Cushing draw – if seen in the EIA data today, it would be the second draw at the Cushing hub, which would further help to dispel concerns about storage issues. Gold is cautiously adding to gains, though is sticky around USD 1,700. Asian indices were mixed overnight (China biased towards lower, though Japan higher), while European bourses have found their way into positive territory. In news flow, we have had retail earnings from Lowe’s (LOW) and Target (TGT) which both topped analyst comp sales estimates and beat on EPS, and withdrew guidance. LOW suggested it saw strong sales continue into May. China’s PBOC left both 1- and 5-year LPR rates unchanged, while investors await this week’s NPC; RBNZ governor Orr cooled talk on negative rates. Data showed European inflation below estimates, and some analysts suggestions about deflation ahead; a similar theme is seen in the UK inflation data. Ahead: FOMC minutes, 20-year bond auction are the main events that stand out; we continue to track further prickly US/China headlines, and news flow on vaccines/treatments (see below).

SECTORS: All sectors open in positive territory with Energy and Industrials leading the gains after leading losses yesterday. The crude complex supporting the former after last night’s private inventory crude & cushing draw. While Industrials are benefiting from gains in Airlines (DAL, UAL, LUV, AAL). Defensives are the laggards today as overall risk sentiment is positive, with Real Estate, Health Care, Utilities the relative underperformers albeit still with slight gains.

EARNINGS: Lowe’s (LOW) saw a solid beat on EPS and revenue while SSS smashed analyst expectations, rising 12.3% (exp. +3.44%). LOW also noted that its strong sales are continuing into May. Target (TGT) also saw top and bottom-line beats with firmer comp sales than expected (+10.8%, exp. +7.5%) driven by a 141% rise in e-commerce; OM’s beat, GM’s missed. Analog Devices (ADI) beat on EPS while revenue was in line, while its guidance was firmer than expected; OM’s beat, GM’s missed. Royal Caribbean (RCL) missed on EPS, and saw a slight revenue beat.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) has reportedly accelerated its plan to move iPhone production to India and Vietnam as it looks to diversify manufacturing risks away from China amid souring US/China relations, according to DigiTimes citing supply chain sources. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) announced it will stop selling its talcum powder in the US and Canada, but it will continue to sell the product outside of North America. Casinos (BYD, PENN, LVS, WYNN, MGM, CZR) in Louisiana, and Mississippi are set to reopen this weekend, while Las Vegas looks set to reopen in June. Google (GOOG) and Dell (DELL) launched a hybrid storage solution to offer simplified management of private and public cloud storage. Roku (ROKU) and AT&T’s (T) WarnerMedia are reportedly aiming for a deal to get HBO Max streaming service on Roku’s platform, but it will not appear on Amazon’s (AMZN) firestick until May 27th, according to Variety. Haliburton (HAL) cut its dividend, Northrop Grumman (NOC) raised its dividend.

ES LEVELS: The Emini S&P 500 saw overnight lows around 2,908, following the late sell-off on Wall Street, though has managed to rise to 2,950, which is key area from a valuation perspective (consensus FY20 expected EPS 138 x 21.4 p/e; FY21 EPS expected 163 x 18.1 p/e). Beneath, desks are continuing to watch 2,930 (61.8% Feb hi-Mar lo) and the region around 2,922-24, 2,900-10 psychological level, and then Monday’s low around 2,850. To the topside, the weekly high 2,976.25, and then the 200dma at 2,997.

GROWTH VS VALUE: Shares of fast-growing companies are racing past their value counterparts, on pace to outperform the latter by the widest margin since the dot-com era, WSJ reports. Goldman Sachs thinks the extreme current valuation gap between the most expensive and least expensive stocks will most likely be closed when an improving economic environment causes the low valuation stocks to ‘catch up’ to the current market leaders.

LESSONS FROM MODERNA: An interesting observation was made by Bloomberg’s market commentator John Authers; recapping this week’s price action, he observes that on Monday Moderna (MRNA) gave an upbeat assessment on the performance of its COVID drug, it then sold shares on Tuesday, and then late on Tuesday, a medical journal said Moderna did not produce data critical to assessing vaccine. The Monday story gave hopes that a second wave can be avoided, and stocks rallied; but Tuesday’s update dragged stocks lower. Authers says “the episode tells us there is more room for the market to rise, if people can be given an excuse,” and “it also shows the depth of desire for someone to come up with a vaccine that can short-circuit what looks like being at least another 12-months of nervousness, fear, ever more fractious politics, and a sluggish economy — and that the current price is based on some bearish assumptions.” Crucially, he argues that the episode demonstrates that, given so few precedents to guide traders, and given the trading community are not scientific experts, it is ‘rival narratives’ which is driving stock price action. The piece is definitely worth a read, and highlights three/four narratives which have been ‘abused’ by markets: “It’s Just A Flu” (used as a justification for minimizing the entire pandemic); “Herd Immunity” (to justify carrying on with economic activity as usual, and risking lives); “Flatten the Curve” (to justify continuing with tight lockdown measures even when they have served their purpose); and possibly “A Vaccine Will Cure Everything.”

subject: Fed's Kaplan (voter) says cannot legislate or stimulate consumer activity; we need to invest in testing so consumers feel safe; thinks the Fed and fiscal authorities will need to do more
analysis_details: His comments on fiscal action and more monetary action are in line with other Fed officials, notably Powell. Powell has previously said the Fed could further help companies with liquidity issues for a while, but over time, more fiscal help will be needed – a strong hint to fiscal policymakers as they debate the next tranche of stimulus. Powell on the weekend said at least three-to-six more months of government support would be required. The Fed chair seems to be arguing that further support is crucial to any recovery, and that if policymakers are careful about how the economy is reopened, and people take these social distancing measures forward, then the recovery can begin fairly soon, and job losses seen since mid-March may prove to be temporary; he also argued that, assuming there is no second wave of the coronavirus, the economy will begin to recover steadily through the second half of this year.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt retrenchment and Dollar reprieve
content: US Treasuries have come under renewed pressure since the cash open with the curve now almost completely flat and long end outperformance unwinding ahead of the 20 year auction. However, the DXY has recovered from another approach towards support ahead of the 99.000 level amidst some paring back of Cad gains in wake of soft Canadian inflation data with a wider 1.3960-1.3878 band. Next up on the midweek agenda, the Wall Street open then flash Eurozone consumer confidence for May before EIA weekly inventories and the FOMC minutes.

US PRE-MARKET THEMES: US futures higher; lessons from Moderna; Ahead: FOMC minutes, 20-year auction
analysis_details:
WHAT’S GOING ON: US equity futures are higher, the VIX is lower, Treasury yields are lower though the front-end is unchanged, the dollar is down for a third day, though is yet to take out Tuesday’s low; oil trades with a positive bias after private inventory data on Tuesday showed headline crude stocks drew down and another Cushing draw – if seen in the EIA data today, it would be the second draw at the Cushing hub, which would further help to dispel concerns about storage issues. Gold is cautiously adding to gains, though is sticky around USD 1,700. Asian indices were mixed overnight (China biased towards lower, though Japan higher); and that dynamic is being seen in Europe/US this morning: European stocks were trading lower, with financials and consumer cyclicals weighing, and health care leading, though Europe has recently entered positive territory. In news flow, we have had retail earnings from Lowe’s (LOW) and Target (TGT) which both topped analyst comp sales estimates and beat on EPS, and withdrew guidance. LOW suggested it saw strong sales continue into May. China’s PBOC left both 1- and 5-year LPR rates unchanged, while investors await this week’s NPC; RBNZ governor Orr cooled talk on negative rates. Data showed European inflation below estimates, and some analysts suggestions about deflation ahead; a similar theme is seen in the UK inflation data. Ahead: FOMC minutes, 20-year bond auction are the main events that stand out; we continue to track further prickly US/China headlines, and news flow on vaccines/treatments (see below).

ES LEVELS: The Emini S&P 500 saw overnight lows around 2,908, following the late sell-off on Wall Street, though has managed to rise to 2,950, which is key area from a valuation perspective (consensus FY20 expected EPS 138 x 21.4 p/e; FY21 EPS expected 163 x 18.1 p/e). Beneath, desks are continuing to watch 2,930 (61.8% Feb hi-Mar lo) and the region around 2,922-24, 2,900-10 psychological level, and then Monday’s low around 2,850. To the topside, the weekly high 2,976.25, and then the 200dma at 2,997.

LESSONS FROM MODERNA: An interesting observation was made by Bloomberg’s market commentator John Authers; recapping this week’s price action, he observes that on Monday Moderna (MRNA) gave an upbeat assessment on the performance of its COVID drug, it then sold shares on Tuesday, and then late on Tuesday, a medical journal said Moderna did not produce data critical to assessing vaccine. The Monday story gave hopes that a second wave can be avoided, and stocks rallied; but Tuesday’s update dragged stocks lower. Authers says “the episode tells us there is more room for the market to rise, if people can be given an excuse,” and “it also shows the depth of desire for someone to come up with a vaccine that can short-circuit what looks like being at least another 12-months of nervousness, fear, ever more fractious politics, and a sluggish economy — and that the current price is based on some bearish assumptions.” Crucially, he argues that the episode demonstrates that, given so few precedents to guide traders, and given the trading community are not scientific experts, it is ‘rival narratives’ which is driving stock price action. The piece is definitely worth a read, and highlights three/four narratives which have been ‘abused’ by markets: “It’s Just A Flu” (used as a justification for minimizing the entire pandemic); “Herd Immunity” (to justify carrying on with economic activity as usual, and risking lives); “Flatten the Curve” (to justify continuing with tight lockdown measures even when they have served their purpose); and possibly “A Vaccine Will Cure Everything.”

GROWTH VS VALUE: Shares of fast-growing companies are racing past their value counterparts, on pace to outperform the latter by the widest margin since the dot-com era, WSJ reports. Goldman Sachs thinks the extreme current valuation gap between the most expensive and least expensive stocks will most likely be closed when an improving economic environment causes the low valuation stocks to ‘catch up’ to the current market leaders.

STIMULUS WATCH: Ahead of the NPC this week (our full preview of the NPC event can be found here), analyst expectations for more stimulus from the Chinese government are building, the FT reports. One analyst said “the NPC will send a clear signal on the level of economic stimulus in the coming months,” and the stimulus “is going to be a strong one, but a runaway building boom is unlikely to happen given the long-term damage it does to the economy.” Meanwhile, there is focus on remarks from JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, which have suggested that central banks will need to ramp-up QE to prevent a sharp rise in bond yields, Bloomberg reported, stating that the level of expected increase in supply this year (around USD 2.1trln) is offsetting the USD 1.9trln demand for bonds by USD 200bln, implying upward pressure on yields, and that more issuance adds to the case for higher rates and steeper curves.

US 20-YEAR BOND AUCTION AT 1PM EDT: The 20-year supply will be the first since 1986. At its quarterly refunding announcement, the US Treasury said it would finally issue its new 20-year maturities on 20th May, for a size of USD 20bln. The size was bigger than anticipated (USD 12-14bln was touted), and with heavier supply at the long-end of the curve, combined with no announcement of a 4- or 6-year tenor, resulted in sharp curve steepening in the wake of the announcement. Analysts at BMO note that takedown seen at the recent 10s and 30s auctions is an encouraging detail for Wednesday's 20-year sale, and points to a solid first auction for the new bond. Click here for preview.

APRIL FOMC MEETING MINUTES AT 2PM EDT: The minutes to the Feb’s April meeting are unlikely to be a game changer, given that the confab itself was considered a ‘holding meeting’, and there have been many Fed speakers in the three weeks that have followed, making the minutes somewhat stale (not that Fed speakers have been saying much, except they will do everything within their mandate to support the economy through this unprecedented times. And that is likely to be the underlying theme of the minutes. Elsewhere, however, we will be on the lookout for commentary on negative rates – which does not carry much favour among Fed members, though is something that they are seemingly keeping in the toolbox in case it is needed in the future – as well as any commentary on yield curve control, which analysts expect the Fed to pivot to in the months ahead to bolster its pledge to keep short-term yields anchored at historic lows for the foreseeable future. Additionally, there will likely be another call on fiscal authorities to help with the heavy lifting. Click here for preview.
